    Development of Indoleamine 2,3-Dioxygenase 1 Inhibitors for Cancer Therapy and Beyond: A Recent Perspective

    • Xi Feng

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 1 (IDO1) has received increasing attention due to its immunosuppressive function in connection with various diseases, including cancer. A recent increase in the understanding of IDO1 has significantly contributed to the discovery of numerous novel inhibitors, but the latest clinical outcomes raised questions and have indicated a future direction of IDO1 inhibition for therapeutic approaches. Herein, we present a comprehensive review of IDO1, discussing the latest advances in understanding the IDO1 structure and mechanism, an overview of recent IDO1 inhibitor discoveries and potential therapeutic applications to provide helpful information for medicinal chemists investigating IDO1 inhibitors.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cancer immunotherapy offers a powerful weapon against solid malignancies with the development of mAbs that target the programmed cell death protein 1/ligand 1 (PD-1/PD-L1) axis and cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 (CTLA-4) and has received significant attention over the past decade. However, a subset of cancer patients does not respond to checkpoint blockade therapy, suggesting the existence of additional tumor immunosuppressive and resistance pathways.(1,2) Preclinical studies have revealed multiple mechanisms contributing to local immunosuppression in the tumor microenvironment (TME), including l-tryptophan (Trp) metabolism.(3,4) Trp is an essential amino acid in mammals, the metabolic fate of which is systematically regulated by various routes.(5) The tryptophan-kynurenine (Trp-Kyn) pathway is the primary route of Trp metabolism, and over 95% of free Trp is consumed and converted to kynurenine (Kyn) and other secondary metabolites through this pathway.(6) Preclinical studies have revealed that heightened Trp-Kyn pathway activity in the TME may contribute to tumor-associated immunosuppression and tumor progression through two proposed molecular mechanisms: depleting local Trp storage and producing pathway metabolites.(3,7â9) Degradation of local Trp is associated with cell cycle arrest and anergy of infiltrating T cells as a consequence of mTOR inhibition and GCN2 activation. However, recent studies have questioned the impact of local Trp degradation on immunomodulation, which may indicate that the immunosuppressive properties of the Trp-Kyn pathway are primarily a consequence of Trp metabolites.(10,11) Accumulated Kyn and its metabolites act as potent agonists of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) and further induce immune modulation by activating regulatory T (Treg) cells and myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs).(12,13) Indeed, the Trp-Kyn pathway has been recognized as a promising target of cancer immunotherapy, but effective strategies for inhibiting this pathway are still under development.
    Along the Trp-Kyn axis, three heme-containing enzymes catalyze the first and rate-limiting step of Trp metabolism to Kyn: indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 1 (IDO1, EC 1.13.11.52), indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 2 (IDO2, EC 1.13.11), and Trp 2,3-dioxygenase (TDO, EC 1.13.11.11). Under catalytic conditions, the Trp substrate is intracellularly oxidized in one reaction with the participation of molecular oxygen (O2) to afford the primary metabolite N-formylkynurenine (NFK).(14) Among the three metabolic enzymes mentioned above, the immunosuppressive impact of IDO1 has been addressed in several preclinical models, and importantly, IDO1 has received the most significant attention from both industry and academia in recent decades.(15â17) To date, thousands of small-molecule compounds have been reported as IDO1 inhibitors, including several clinical candidates, although they are still in proof-of-concept trials. Preclinical studies and clinical data have supported that the majority of cancer cells and intratumoral cells express IDO1, and elevated IDO1 activity and Kyn levels are associated with advanced tumor grade and poor prognosis in a variety of cancer types.(18,19) In addition, IDO1 is also involved in the development of resistance against immune checkpoint blockade therapies.(1,20,21) Based on the promising potential of IDO1, dozens of clinical trials on IDO1 inhibitors have been launched as monotherapies or in combination with immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) for the treatment of cancers. It had been widely anticipated that the leading IDO1 candidates would pass clinical tests and reach approval; however, the recent failure of a phase 3 trial testing an IDO1 inhibitor has highlighted the need for deeper insight into the Trp-Kyn pathway in diseases, raising new questions on the design of better and more rationalized compounds targeting the pathway coupled with improved rationalized trial design.(22,23)
    The more recently identified IDO1-related enzyme IDO2 has a distinct expression pattern and exhibits lower Trp degradation activity.(24) Although the physiological functions of IDO2 and its roles in disease conditions involving the Trp-Kyn pathway remain unclear, this IDO1-related enzyme has been found to be expressed in some cancer cells and is considered to support IDO1-mediated immune tolerance.(8,24,25) In addition to IDO2, TDO, which was initially thought to be a hepatic enzyme responsible for metabolizing dietary Trp, is ectopically expressed by malignant cells in some cancers and has been implicated in both immune tolerance and metastatic progression.(26,27) A recent understanding of the molecular pathway in Trp metabolism-linked local immunosuppression indicates that intratumoral TDO similarly restrains the antitumor response and suppresses tumor immune infiltration.(12,26) Preclinical studies have revealed that TDO could serve as an additional target for sufficient Trp-Kyn pathway inhibition and durable immunosuppression relief.(12,26) Currently, two IDO1/TDO dual inhibitors are in clinical evaluations for the treatment of cancer.(28,29) In this review, we summarize the latest understanding of IDO1 and highlight the discovery and structural features of recently disclosed IDO1 inhibitors.

    Structure and Mechanisms of IDO

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Structure and Active Sites of IDO1

    Human IDO1 (hIDO1) is a monomeric oxidase expressed in most tissues at low levels that contains a large C-terminal domain (CTD) and a small N-terminal domain (NTD). The CTD comprises a large domain that anchors the heme cofactor and accounts for the catalytic activity of IDO1, while the NTD contains two small domains that are implicated in signaling functions and defined as immunoreceptor tyrosine-based inhibitory motifs (ITIMs) (Figure 1A).(30â33) Since 2006, the crystal structures of hIDO1 in complex with Trp and a variety of inhibitors have been disclosed.(34â37) Most of these inhibitors occupy the active site (Sa) of the catalytically competent heme-bound IDO1 (holoIDO1), where coordination to heme could be generated via an N atom or an O atom of the inhibitors (iron coordination could theoretically also be generated by S atom). Structurally, the Sa site of IDO1 is located at the CTD and comprises two distinct clefts: a deeper hydrophobic pocket A inside the protein that contains a heme group as the key moiety for the substrate conversion and an outward pocket B at the entrance of the binding site.(38) In addition, a distal pocket nearing the solvent region is named pocket C but is rarely exploited.(39)
    In 2017, the crystal structure of the hIDO1âTrp complex reported by Lewis-Ballester et al. revealed that the Trp substrate is located in the distal heme pocket, and the indole group is located perpendicular upon the heme ring and is surrounded by a group of hydrophobic residues from pocket A (PDB id: 5WMV, Figure 1A).(34) The indole group is further secured by key residue Ser167 and interacts with the heme group via an intervening iron-bound CN molecule; meanwhile, the backbone of Trp extends into pocket B, and the carboxylate group is stabilized by a polar interaction with Arg231, which is considered critical for recognizing and binding substrates.(14,34) Simultaneously, the crystal structure of IDO1 in complex with epacadostat (PDB id: 5WN8, Table 1, Figure 1B), which has been the most advanced IDO1 inhibitor in clinical trials, has been reported to exhibit a similar binding mode to the hIDO1âTrp complex.(34) Pocket A is occupied by the bulky benzene group, which is surrounded by a group of hydrophobic residues, including Phe126, Val130, Phe164, Leu234, Phe163, and Ser167.(34) The terminal halogen atoms are adjacent to Cys129 in the N-terminal domain, leading to an additional fluorineâsulfur contact that is considered beneficial for protein inhibitor stabilization.(34) The linear alkyl chain extends into pocket B, and the sulfamide group is further anchored by Arg231.(34) Uniquely, epacadostat coordinates to the heme iron via an O atom of the hydroxyamidine group, which is distinguished from other IDO1âheme-inhibitor complexes in which heme has been considered blocked by N-iron-mediated coordination. Another exception is PF-06840003 (Table 1, Figure 2A), a clinical candidate IDO1 inhibitor that has been observed to sit perpendicular to the heme group with no direct interaction with the central iron.(37) In recent years, with the support of crystal structure and in silico simulation of the IDO1âinhibitor complex, it has been recognized that most high-affinity inhibitors usually branch two fragments into both pockets A and B, while inhibitors with smaller scaffolds typically occupy only pocket A and may exhibit deficient potency. Structureâactivity relationship (SAR) studies performed by medicinal chemists have indicated that seeking additional interactions with key residues in pocket B, such as Arg231, is beneficial for improving the inhibitory efficacy.
    Table 1. Selected Small-Molecule Inhibitors Targeting IDO1 in Clinical Trials
    Recent studies of the heme-competitive inhibitor BMS986205 (Table 1, Figure 1C) have revealed a unique inhibitory mechanism, as well as a distinct binding mode of IDO1 inhibitor. Nelp et al. reported that BMS986205 irreversibly inhibits IDO1 activity by targeting its intrinsic apo-form, which is the enzyme without the prosthetic group, blocking the rebinding of heme.(35) Another report by Ortiz-Meoz et al. also supported that their IDO1 inhibitor, GSK5628 (Figure 5), inhibits IDO1 by binding to the heme-free form and preventing enzymatic reactivation.(40) However, studies from Pham et al. delineated a process of heme release triggered by BMS986205, which ultimately leads to a distinct conformation of inhibitor in the IDO1 binding site.(36) Despite disagreements and questions regarding the mechanism of heme-competitive inhibitors, these reported compounds usually exhibit more potent activities in cellular assays, which may further indicate that apo-IDO1 may represent an efficient target for IDO1 inhibition.(35,40â43) Supported by coordination via the His346-iron bond, the heme group covers its proximal site, which was previously identified as the inhibitory substrate binding site (Si site, Figure 1A), and the release of heme makes this spacious hydrophobic cavity (also called pocket D) accessible for small molecular inhibitors.(34,44) According to the crystal structures of the hIDO1âBMS986205/BMS116 complex (PDB id: 6MQ6/6AZW, Figure 1C), the inhibitors occupy both pockets A and D in stretched conformations: (i) the phenyl group occupies hydrophobic pocket A, and the propanamide moiety is further secured by hydrogen bonds (H-bonds) from Ser167 and His346; (ii) the quinoline group extends to the additional pocket and is surrounded by a group of hydrophobic residues, including Phe270, Leu342, and Ala174, which is further stabilized by Ï-stacking with Phe270 and an H-bond with Arg343.(35,36)
    Through deep analysis of the crystal structure, it has been realized that the binding pocket of IDO1 is shaped according to the bound inhibitor.(16) Diverse inhibitors may induce conformational rearrangements that further change the volume of the catalytic site. Recent studies have suggested that binding of inhibitors in the Sa site may also induce conformational changes in the remote small domain in NTD, indicating that inhibitors may further affect signaling and contribute to additional efficacy.(45) In addition to catalytic activity, IDO1 also acts as a signal-transducing molecule that plays a basic role in immunological and inflammatory modulation.(31,32) The IDO1 signaling function relies on two ITIMs (ITIM1 and 2) that are both located quite distant from the catalytic site (Figure 1A). Phosphorylated ITIMs act as docking sites that allow IDO1 to associate with different molecular partners responsible for different physiological effects: phosphorylation of ITIM1 triggers immunosuppressive effects by binding to the protein tyrosine phosphatases (SHP1 and SHP2) and inducing sustained IDO1 expression; in contrast, phosphorylated ITIM2 binds to the suppressor of cytokine signaling 3 (SOCS3) and accelerates proteasomal degradation of IDO1, which promotes inflammatory responses.(30â33)
    Structure-based drug design (SBDD) is an efficient approach in modern drug development for specific targets, but a deeper insight into hIDO1âligand interactions within the binding site of the target is necessary. In silico virtual screening (VS) has attracted attention as a complementary approach to high-throughput screening (HTS) and has contributed to the identification of novel IDO1 inhibitors in many cases. Despite 45 entries of IDO1 structures that have been disclosed in the protein data bank (PDB) database (Table S1), few of these entries have been employed in the VS campaign.(45,46) The flexibility of IDO1 may cause problems for IDO1 docking studies, as the binding region in the receptor is usually held rigid compared to ligands.(15) Another issue is that the presence of heme iron interacts with the ligands in the docking experiment, and importantly, it has been difficult to reliably describe the electronic environment of the heme in computational simulation. Hence, pretests, such as native-docking and cross-docking processes based on the reported IDO1 crystallographic coordinates, might be beneficial prior to a VS campaign.(47)

    Structures and Biofunctions of TDO and IDO2

    Although the focus in targeting the Trp-Kyn pathway has been largely on IDO1, two other related Trp metabolism enzymes have also been considered potential therapeutic targets. Importantly, recent observations, as well as clinical outcomes, have supported that the development of combined IDO/TDO inhibitors may represent an advanced and future strategy in this field.(22,48) The TDO enzyme is a homotetramer with a distinct structural basis compared to IDO1, while the distal heme pocket in the Sa site of TDO is similar to that of IDO1.(49) The recently disclosed crystal structures of TDOâsubstrate and inhibitor complexes (PDB id: 6PYY, Figure 1D) have revealed structural insights into TDO, including (i) the Sa site in TDO has been observed to be rigid in contrast to IDO1, which may be responsible for restricting substrate selectivity and further imply the challenge of characterizing specific scaffolds of potent TDO inhibitors, (ii) the indole-based compounds occupy pocket âAâ with their indole groups, where the indole rings are surrounded by a set of hydrophobic residues, including Phe72, Leu46, and Phe45, and the N atoms of indole scaffolds interact with His76 (equivalent to Ser167 of IDO1) through an H-bond, while the succinimide moieties extend to pocket âBâ and are further anchored by Arg144, which could be considered Arg231 in IDO1, and (iii) pocket âDâ on the proximal side of the enzyme is blocked by bulky residues; correspondingly, a distant exo site exists and binds to Trp for cellular stability rather than catalytic activity.(49,50)
    In addition, the IDO2 protein shares 43% sequence homology with IDO1 but exhibits distinct physiological activities.(51) Observations have suggested that IDO2 may be part of the feedforward loop of IDO1-induced Trp metabolism, as the IDO2 gene is regulated in response to the downstream AhR of the IDO1 pathway.(8,51) IDO2 has also emerged as a potential target, and recent studies have reported several compounds with micromolar IC50 values against IDO2, whereas challenges remain in the establishment of IDO2 enzymatic assays and avoidance of cross-reactivity to IDO1.(52â54) As a homologue of IDO1, IDO2 comprises an active site similar to IDO1, which may support the correlation of dual inhibitory activity of IDO1/IDO2.(52) However, IDO2 exhibits extremely low activity of Trp degradation only in vitro, and the biological significance of IDO2 has also been questioned in the literature.(24,55,56)

    Mechanism of IDO1 and Its Inhibition

    Studies have shown the low substrate specificity of IDO1 and that other indole-bearing compounds (e.g., melatonin, serotonin, and tryptamine) could serve as substrates.(57,58) With the help of a heme cofactor, IDO1 oxidatively cleaves the 2,3-position of the indole ring in Trp to produce NFK using dioxygen. To initiate the reaction, the reduced ferrous (Fe2+) state of heme iron is required, and a reductant is necessary to reactivate the enzyme as IDO1 is prone to autoxidation. Therefore, ascorbate and methylene blue (MB) are usually employed for enzymatic assays in vitro. It has been shown that two substrates of IDO1 are involved in the catalytic cycle, including Trp and O2. Binding of O2 to the heme cofactor is recognized as the first step prior to the binding of Trp.(59,60) Accordingly, a heme superoxide intermediate is formed and consequently attacks Trp via two possible pathways: an electrophilic addition or a radical addition.(61) These two additional reactions both contribute to the formation of another key intermediate, Trp epoxide, as the precursor of the ring-opening product.
    The substrate inhibition behavior of IDO1 at a high-level concentration of Trp was previously noted, but the mechanism is still under debate.(62,63) It has been suggested that this substrate-controlled regulation is responsible for balancing levels of Trp-Kyn pathway metabolites when dietary Trp levels increase.(50) Previous studies indicated that substrate inhibition of IDO1 might be a result of the reversed binding order of O2 and Trp when Trp is present at high levels.(60,64) Interestingly, recent studies by Yeh et al. reported that a second Trp could bind to the inhibitory Si site, suggesting an explanation for the substrate inhibition behavior (Figure 1A).(34,65) Questions about this mechanism remain as Trp binding to pocket D was only detected in the F270G mutant of hIDO1. That is, bulky residues in wild-type IDO1, including Phe214 and Phe270, may restrict the accessibility of pocket D. A recent study by this group revealed that substrate-induced inhibition is a result of Trp epoxide detaining, which was rescued by an effector 3-indole ethanol (IDE) bound in pocket D.(66) Furthermore, the S167H mutant in IDO1, which abolishes enzymatic activity, is implicated in slowing O2 binding with ferrous heme.(66) A more recent study by Mondanelli et al. indicated that the Trp metabolite N-acetylserotonin potentiates IDO1 catalytic activity as a positive allosteric modulator by binding to pocket D of IDO1.(67) In general, these independent studies revealed the possible biological function of the Si site in modulating enzymatic activity and further supported pocket D as a potential binding site for IDO1 inhibition.
    Based on current understanding, present IDO1 inhibitors are classified according to their inhibition kinetics. Recently, RÃ¶hrig et al. proposed a classification comprising 5 defined types of IDO1 inhibitors.(44) Type I, II, and III inhibitors bind to heme-bound IDO1 in the Sa site and prevent the initial steps of substrate binding, whereas type IV inhibitors (e.g., BMS986205) occupy the heme-free apo-IDO1 for inhibition activities. Specifically, type I inhibitors (e.g., L-1 MT, Figure 2A) bind to O2-bound heme IDO1 in competition with Trp, while type II inhibitors (e.g., epacadostat) interact with active ferrous-heme (Fe2+) and compete with O2 for the six-iron binding site. Compounds such as 4-phenylimidazole (4PI, Figure 3A), which has been suggested to bind to ferric-heme IDO1 and hinder the reductive reactivation of enzymes, are described as type III inhibitors. In addition, compounds with an inhibitory activity that act by perturbing the redox cycle, particularly quinone-based compounds, do not specifically target the IDO1 enzyme and are thus defined as type X inhibitors.

    Assays for Screening IDO1 Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The common preliminary evaluation employed in compound screening is indicated by target inhibitory assays based on either recombinant human IDO1 (rhIDO1) protein or cell lines, through monitoring and detecting concentration changes in Trp or enzymatic reaction products. Literature by RÃ¶hrig et al. and related references have exhaustively described and explained the enzymatic assays and cellular assays of small molecular compounds that induce IDO1 inhibition.(15) It should be noted that, in many cases, inhibitory values in the cellular assay may be better than results from the enzyme-based assay, which is unusual, as various issues, including permeability, may lower the potency in cellular conditions. The incompetent rhIDO1 protein environment and complex catalytic cycle in vivo have been considered responsible for divergent results, such as different pH values, different reducing cofactors, and oxidation states.(15) Intriguingly, studies of newly characterized heme-competitive inhibitors have indicated that these compounds display the most significant inhibitory activities with single-digit nanomolar IC50 values in cellular assays, whereas insufficient potency was observed in enzymatic assays, except under prolonged incubation times and elevated temperatures.(41) On the other hand, testing quinone-based inhibitors in enzymatic assays usually leads to nanomolar potency. In the cell-based assay, quinones could undergo redox cycling in the cellular environment; therefore, cytochrome P450 reductase/NADPH and cytochrome b5 could be used as reductants to clarify the inhibitory results.(68)
    In cellular assays, IDO1 protein is initially expressed by tool cells under certain stimulation conditions prior to treatment with test compounds. Expression of IDO1 protein is usually achieved in two ways: (i) stimulating cells with interferon Î³ (IFNÎ³) and (ii) transfecting cells with ido1 recombinant plasmid. The IFNÎ³-stimulated cell line employed in IDO1 cellular evaluation could be a cancer cell line, including HeLa, MDA-MB-231, THP1, SKOV3, A375, LXF289, MCF7, HepG2, and DAN-G cells, or human whole blood and peripheral blood mononuclear cells. On the other hand, the HEK293 cell line is commonly used to express IDO1 protein before performing cellular assays, as well as murine P1. HTR cells.

    IDO1 Inhibitors in Clinical Development

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Recent years have witnessed many attempts to identify and develop potential IDO1 inhibitors since the participation of IDO1 in oncogenesis was first uncovered in 2003.(69) Despite a large number of IDO1 inhibitors reported in the literature and patent applications, only a few compounds have entered clinical trials. To the best of our knowledge, eight remaining new chemical entity (NCE) candidates for use as IDO1 inhibitors are currently undergoing clinical evaluation for the treatment of cancers as monotherapies or in combination with ICIs. Notably, only six candidates have been structurally disclosed, including three advanced compounds that have entered phase 3 clinical evaluation (Table 1). Despite promising results that have emerged in preclinical and initial studies, negative outcomes of potential candidates in the past 2 years have brought the viability of IDO1 inhibition into question and urged essential speculation and further evaluation of this approach. Recent studies have highlighted the clinical progression of IDO1 inhibitors;(7,70,71) here, we briefly present the structural basis of small-molecule clinical candidates with recent advances and opinions on IDO1 inhibitors in clinical trials.
    Trp analogue 1 (indoximod, NLG8189, D-1 MT, Table 1) is the first clinical candidate developed by NewLink Co., Ltd. and has been evaluated in a phase 3 clinical trial administered with ICIs beginning in 2017 for the treatment of melanoma. In addition, the prodrug form of 1 coded NLG802 (6) entered phase 1 clinical trials in 2017.(72,73) However, 1 and its prodrug are not specific IDO1 inhibitors (hIDO1 IC50 > 100 mM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 > 2.5 mM for 1), and their mechanism of action remains controversial.(3) Indeed, studies have suggested that 1 has pleiotropic effects on downstream signaling of the Trp-Kyn pathway.(74,75) Another IDO1 inhibitor 2 (epacadostat, INCB24360, Table 1) is an N-hydroxyamidine derivative developed by Incyte Co., Ltd., through the HTS strategy and the first candidate compound entered phase 3 as a selective IDO1 inhibitor (hIDO1 IC50 = 73 nM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 7.4 nM).(76) Unexpectedly, the first large phase 3 trial (ECHO-301/KEYNOTE-252) did not meet its two end points and was terminated in April 2018; namely, 2 did not provide evidential benefit for survival.(77) Questions and discussions have emerged regarding this failure. One of the key phenomena is that inhibition of Kyn was insufficient in vivo, which may be a result of multiple factors, including selective IDO1 inhibition.(22) Despite the negative outcomes of clinical studies, 2 has served as a model lead for numerous mimics, as the N-hydroxyamidine scaffold exhibits good potential for inhibitory activities.(16) The quinoline-containing compound 3 (BMS-986205, linrodostat, Table 1) from Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. (originator Flexus) is a heme-competitive inhibitor (also defined as âsuicide inhibitorâ in the literature) that exhibits the best cell-based potencies (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 0.5 nM).(35) In 2018, Bristol-Myers Squibb launched a large phase 3 clinical trial of 3 to recruit 1200 patients with bladder cancer.(78) Recently, however, two of the phase 3 trials with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) and nonsmall cell lung cancer (NSCLC) to evaluate 3 have been withdrawn due to changed business objectives. The 4-phenylimidazole derivative 4 (navoximod, GDC0919, NLG919, Table 1) is another approach of NewLink Co., Ltd. and has finished its phase 1 trial as a selective IDO1 inhibitor (hIDO1 IC50 = 28 nM, 293 IDO1 EC50 = 75 nM).(79) Despite the moderate IDO1 inhibitory activity and preclinical antitumor efficacy, a further clinical program using 4 ceased in 2017. Recent literature by Kumar et al. systematically described the discovery of this tricyclic compound and revealed the structural basis of its activity.(79) Indole-based compound 5 (PF-06840003, EOS-200271, Table 1) from Pfizer Inc. (originator iTeos) is a selective IDO1 inhibitor (hIDO1 IC50 = 0.41 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 1.8 Î¼M), which has been evaluated in phase 1 clinical trials for the treatment of malignant gliomas.(37) Similarly, further clinical development of 5 was suspended in 2018. The 5-bearing indole group has been a reliable scaffold for medicinal researchers as a mimic of Trp, especially in the preliminary stage. However, the reported indole derivatives usually show moderate potencies with micromolar activities. Indoline derivative 7 (LY3381916, Table 1) was developed by Lilly as a selective IDO1 inhibitor and has been in phase 1 clinical evaluation for the treatment of cancer since 2017. Compound 7 was reported to act as a heme-competitive inhibitor with a single-digit nanomolar IC50 value (cell IDO1 IC50 = 7 nM) in a cell-based assay.(80) However, in 2020, this phase 1 trial was terminated.(81) In addition, another two undisclosed IDO1 inhibitors, KHK-2455 from Hakko Kirin and MK-7162 from Merck, are currently under active phase 1 trials for the treatment of unspecific solid tumors.(82,83)
    Notably, in 2019, a phase 1 program launched by Hengrui Co., Ltd., to evaluate HTI-1090 (SHR-9146, structure undisclosed) as an IDO1/TDO dual inhibitor was completed, and further evaluation was planned.(28,84) Subsequently, another IDO1/TDO dual inhibitor DN1406131 (structure undisclosed) developed by De Novo Pharmatech has entered a phase 1 trial for the treatment of cancer.(29)

    Recently Disclosed IDO1 Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A large variety of compound series has emerged as IDO1 inhibitors in recent years. In previous studies, some IDO1 inhibitors have been classified according to their structural scaffolds, providing a significant foundation for researchers in this field.(15) Hence, in the following section, we primarily focus on renewing the classification and updating the recently published IDO1 inhibitors based on their structural basis and interaction details during the period of 2016â2020.

    Inhibitors Targeting the Sa Site of holoIDO1

    Trp/Indole Analogues

    Many Trp analogues or indole-based scaffolds were first identified as IDO1 inhibitors and provided important proof-of-principle demonstrations in early stages.(16) 1-Methyl-Trp (1 MT) has been the most frequently used IDO1 inhibitor, showing moderate inhibitory activities. However, two stereoisomers of 1-MT exhibit distinct potencies: (i) D-1 MT (1), described above, is a clinical candidate in a phase 3 trial as a Trp-Kyn pathway inhibitor and does not inhibit IDO1 in vitro; (ii) on the other hand, L-1 MT (8, Figure 2A) serves as the substrate competitor and inhibits IDO1 with moderate activity (hIDO1 IC50 = 42 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 18.4 Î¼M).(47,85) Previously, Trp-derived inhibitors were typically reported with moderate inhibitory activities that bear an indole group and various side chains. Recently, disclosed structures of IDO1âindole complexes have revealed that the indole group stands perpendicular on the heme group, and importantly, the N atom is adjacent to Ser167 and does not directly coordinate to the iron in heme.(34,37) This unique binding mode could be a specific feature of Trp/indole analogues, and the lack of coordination with heme iron may be responsible for their moderate potencies.
    In 2016, Coluccia et al. reported a series of indole derivatives as IDO1 inhibitors based on a VS campaign, and 3-arylthioindole derivative 9 (Figure 2A) was identified with moderate activity (hIDO1 IC50 = 7 Î¼M).(86) Subsequently, another 3-substituted indole derivative 10 (Figure 2A) was identified through a VS campaign and was further demonstrated to be a potential lead with moderate binding affinity and inhibitory activity (hIDO1 Kd = 17.8 Î¼M, cell-based IDO1 IC50 = 14.4 Î¼M).(87) Similar to 1 MT, recent studies have reported that two enantiomers of clinical candidate 5 showed distinct priority in inhibitory activities, whereas candidate 5 has been clinically employed as a racemic complex.(37,88) Interestingly, it was shown that compound 11 (PF-06840002, Figure 2A), which is the R-enantiomer of 5, functions as an enantiomer and is approximately 190-fold more potent than the inactive S-enantiomer (hIDO1 IC50 = 0.20 Î¼M and HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 1.0 Î¼M for 11 versus hIDO1 IC50 > 10 Î¼M and HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 13 Î¼M for S-5).(37) Although racemate 5 (hIDO1 IC50 = 0.41 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 1.8 Î¼M) is less potent than the active enantiomer, rapid autoracemization of 11 in plasma negated the benefits of using a single enantiomer for further tests.(37,88) The crystal structure of the hIDO1â11 complex (PDB id: 5WHR, Figure 2A) indicated that the succinimide ring lies parallel to the heme without direct interaction with iron, while the indole group stands perpendicular to the heme, interacts with Ser167, and occupies pocket A.(37)
    Some indole analogues have also been developed as IDO1 inhibitors in recent years. In 2016, Pantouris et al. reported an oxindole derivative 12 (Figure 2B) based on the isatin scaffold as an IDO1/TDO dual inhibitor (hIDO1 Ki = 1 Î¼M, hTDO Ki = 4 Î¼M).(89) The next year, Paul et al. reported a series of 3-substituted oxindoles as selective IDO1 inhibitors with submicromolar activities, including 1-(5-chloro-2-oxoindolin-3-ylidene)pentane-2,4-dione 13 (Figure 2B, hIDO1 IC50 = 0.19 Î¼M, MDA-MB-231 IDO1 IC50 = 0.33 Î¼M).(90) Importantly, the in silico docking experiments indicated that the oxindole derivatives bind to IDO1 with a typical âindole-likeâ binding mode, except 2-carbonyl orienting to heme.(90) A more recently published study by Cui et al. reported their efforts in investigating indole-2-carboxylic acid derivatives for IDO1 inhibition.(91) The most potent compound 14 (Figure 2B) exhibited dual inhibitory activities against IDO1/TDO with IC50 values of 1.17 Î¼M and 1.55 Î¼M, respectively. SAR studies revealed that the 2-carboxyl group is essential for inhibitory activity, which was further demonstrated to be an electron donor for binding with a key residue rather than heme iron. Interestingly, one oxidation product (9p-O from ref (91)) was accidentally found and exhibited significant improvement of inhibitory activity (hIDO1 IC50 = 18 nM, hTDO IC50 = 25 nM) compared to the original compound in the enzymatic assay.(91) However, most of the compounds exhibited poor activities in cellular assays, and attention should be paid to the fact that the autoxidation reaction and the oxidative product 9p-O (a benzoquinone derivative) could both affect the oxidation state of IDO1 for enzymatic inhibitory activity.
    In addition, a group of indazole derivatives has shown promising potential in IDO1 inhibition. Qian and co-workers reported the discovery of 4,6-substituted-1H-indazoles as IDO1 inhibitors with micromolar IC50 values (Figure 2C).(92,93) It was demonstrated that a halogen atom at the 6-position is important for the inhibitory activity, and 15 (Figure 2C) emerged as an initial lead (hIDO1 IC50 = 5.3 Î¼M).(72) Later, in a separate study, the authors optimized the side chains at the 4-position and reported 16 (Figure 2C) bearing the benzo-oxadiazole group with improved potency (hIDO1 IC50 = 0.74 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 1.37 Î¼M), which further exhibited antitumor efficacy in vivo.(73) Simultaneously, Tsujino et al. reported another 4,6-disubstituted indazole 17 (Figure 2C) with moderate binding affinity to ferrous hIDO1 (Kd = 0.14 Î¼M).(94) Importantly, the direct coordination between a model compound of 4-trimethylsilyl-6-methyl-1H-indazole (compound 1 in ref (94)) and IDO1 was observed through a spectroscopy test. A further docking study of 17 suggested that the indazole ring stands perpendicular to the heme group, while the phenylethanol moiety on the C4 position extends to pocket B. These results may indicate that the indazole derivatives are more like inhibitors of the following group according to their similar binding mode.

    Imidazole/Triazole Derivatives

    The first lead scaffold was 4PI (Figure 3A). 4PI is a known heme binder that was previously identified as a weak IDO1 inhibitor (hIDO1 IC50 = 48 Î¼M) in 1989, and its cocrystallization with IDO1 (PDB id: 2D0T, Figure 3A) first revealed its interaction as an inhibitor in the binding site in 2006.(14,95,96) It has been recognized that 4PI is located at the Sa site and coordinates to the heme iron through its N1 atom of the imidazole group and occupies pocket A with a phenyl group. In addition, pocket B is further occupied by two molecules of 2-(N-cyclohexylamino)ethane sulfonic acid in this crystal form, which is the additive component of the crystallization buffer. These initial crystal structures have paved the way for structure-based in silico design of IDO1 inhibitors and provided a structural basis for developing phenylimidazole derivatives based on the binding mode. The previous modification of the lead 4PI has been focused on screening substituents on the phenyl group and has led to various derivatives with minor optimization and moderate IC50 values. Recently, further screening of phenylimidazole derivatives has been reported with significantly improved potencies by searching for additional interactions in unoccupied pocket B. In 2016, Fallarini et al. screened a series of disubstituted imidazole derivatives based on an in silico strategy for better IDO1 inhibition.(97) According to subsequent evaluation, 4,5-diaryl-substituted derivatives emerged with improved activities, including 18 (Figure 3A, hIDO1 IC50 = 2.8 Î¼M, A375 IDO1 IC50 = 2.9 Î¼M), whereas 1,5-disubstituted compounds almost showed inefficiency in this screening. The docking pose of 18 indicated that the designed p-acetamidophenyl group may extend into pocket B, while the 4-phenyl imidazole motif is similar to lead 4PI. In subsequent work, 1,5-disubstituted imidazole derivatives were reported with nanomolar activities in enzymatic assays and lower micromolar activities in cellular assays. Specifically, 19 (Figure 3A) with a 5-fluoroindole group at the N1-position, which was speculated to bind in pocket B, showed the most potent activity for IDO1 inhibition (hIDO1 IC50 = 33.8 nM, HEK293 IDO1 IC50 = 0.26 Î¼M).(98) The chlorophenol ring may occupy pocket A and be stabilized by an interaction between the hydroxyl group and Ser167, which shares a common scaffold with a previously reported 4-phenyl-1,2,3-triazole IDO1 inhibitor 20 (Figure 3A, hIDO1 IC50 = 0.33 Î¼M).(99) However, bioisosteric replacements of the imidazole ring in 4PI with various five-membered nitrogen-containing rings have shown high selectivity in enzymatic inhibition due to their complicated electronic nature.(15) RÃ¶hrig et al. further evaluated and reported the potential of 4-phenyl-1,2,3-triazole derivatives as IDO2 inhibitors that showed selectivity toward IDO1.(52) In 2018, 4-amino-1,2,3-triazole 21 (Figure 3A) was discovered through HTS with potent cellular activities (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 23 nM, HEK293 IDO1 IC50 = 67 nM); however, much weaker enzymatic inhibitory activity was observed (hIDO1 IC50 = 11.3 Î¼M).(100) According to the cocomplex crystal of 21-bound IDO1 (PDB id: 6F0A), 21 is located at pocket A of IDO1 in a binding mode similar to that of 4PI, including one additional buffer-sourced l-alanine molecule in pocket B interacting with Arg231, propionate group of heme, and N3 atom of 21. Importantly, extended kinetic and spectroscopic studies demonstrated that 21 is prone to forming a tighter complex with ferrous IDO1 (Kd = 2.3 Î¼M) compared to ferric IDO1 with the slow association and dissociation kinetics, which shows, namely, a distinct inhibitory mechanism with 4PI. Later, in 2019, Panda et al. reported 4,5-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole derivatives with nanomolar activities both in enzymatic and cellular IDO1 inhibition assays and potent activities in an in vivo antitumor assay.(101) The initial compound 22 (Figure 3A) with a carboxamide group at the C4-position showed good potencies (hIDO1 IC50 = 110 nM, MDA-MB-231 IDO1 EC50 = 74 nM), while further optimization, including installing a sulfamide group in the 4-carboxamide moiety (compound 4k from ref (101)) for occupying pocket B, barely improved the inhibitory activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 92 nM, MDA-MB-231 IDO1 EC50 = 74 nM).(101) Compounds 20â22 are examples of potent inhibitors that only occupy pocket A.
    Tricyclic compounds bearing the fused phenyl-imidazole scaffold were initially described in an application of NewLink Co., Ltd., as potent IDO1 inhibitors in 2012.(102) Indeed, the search for phenylimidazole derivatives as IDO1 inhibitors has been intensely pursued by NewLink, and tricyclic imidazoisoindoles were then developed as a result of rational drug design based on lead 4PI. Reducing the rotatable bonds for molecular rigidification has been a potential strategy for improving the binding affinity and potency of small-molecule inhibitors, which was successful and led to the discovery of clinical candidate 4 according to a recently disclosed literature by NewLink.(79) Fused rigid imidazo[5,1-a]isoindole initially emerged as a promising lead with improved IDO1 inhibitory activity (hIDO1 IC50 = 5.7 Î¼M) through incorporating a methylene linker at the N1 and 2â²-positions of 4PI, and the related derivative with ethylcyclohexyl at the C5-position was subsequently found with an enzymatic IC50 value of 0.135 Î¼M. Further optimization for the purpose of interacting with the propionate group of heme and Ser235 or Arg231 of pocket B was achieved by introducing additional hydroxyl groups at the C11 and C15 positions, which finally led to 4 as selective IDO1 inhibitors with nanomolar activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 28 nM, 293 IDO1 EC50 = 75 nM). Importantly, the cocrystal structure of 4 bound to IDO1 (PDB id: 6O3I, Figure 3A) revealed that the imidazoisoindole core coordinates to heme iron with the N2 atom, and the phenyl group fits in hydrophobic pocket A, which may account for the dramatic and negative impact of halogen substituents at the C7 or C8 position.(79) In addition, imidazoisoindole 23 (Figure 3A), bearing a longer side chain, was reported by Laiâs group in 2017 with moderate activities in a cellular assay (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 0.84 Î¼M).(103) In subsequent work, another imidazoisoindole derivative, 24 (Figure 3A), was developed by Hengrui as a potent IDO1/TDO dual inhibitor with nanomolar activities in both enzymatic and cellular assays (hIDO1 IC50 = 9.7 nM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 76 nM, hTDO IC50 = 47 nM) and exhibited favorable pharmacokinetic (PK) properties, including improved cytochrome p450 enzyme inhibition profiles.(104) Docking studies indicated that the extended side chain stuck deeper into pocket B, while the methylpyrazol group engaged in a cationâÏ interaction with Arg231, which was speculated to be a reason for potent IDO1 inhibitory activity.(104)
    Thiazolotriazole 25 (AMG-1, Figure 3B) was initially developed by Amgen in 2011 through the HTS strategy and was reported as a selective IDO1 inhibitor with an IC50 value of 3 Î¼M.(55) Later, the crystal structure of the hIDO1â25 complex (PDB id: 4PK5, Figure 3B) confirmed the coordination between the N atom of triazole and heme iron, which led to the identification of imidazothiazole derivatives with nanomolar activities.(105) Recently, imidazothiazole 26 (Figure 3B) was reported by Pirali et al. with moderate activity (hIDO1 IC50 = 0.2 Î¼M), and in their subsequent work, compound 27 (Figure 3B) was synthesized, exploiting click chemistry, and showed equivalent inhibitory activity (hIDO1 IC50 = 0.2 Î¼M).(39,106) Among the reported compounds, p-bromophenyl at the C3-position was demonstrated to be crucial for activity, whereas a linearly rigid linker bearing hydroxyl or cyano groups at its terminus was beneficial for interacting with Phe226 and Arg231 in pocket B.(39,105) A more recent study reported the discovery of thiourea-based 28 (Figure 3B), a highly potent IDO1 inhibitor (hIDO1 IC50 = 16.4 nM), through rational structural optimization.(107) The S1 atom of the imidazothiazole core forms an SâO interaction with gate residue Ser167, and specifically, the unique (prop-1-ynyl)-cyclopropane moiety at the C3-position occupies pocket A and forms an additional interaction with Cys129 via the cyclopropane ring, which exhibits a Ï-like property.(107) Furthermore, the cocrystal structure of hIDO1â28 (PDB id: 6KOF, Figure 3B) also revealed that an additional sulfurâaromatic interaction network was established between the thiourea moiety and the neighboring Phe163/Phe226, which may account for a 6-fold improvement in IDO1 inhibition compared to urea-based 29 (Figure 3B, hIDO1 IC50 = 102 nM).(107) However, imidazothiazole inhibitors usually showed moderate to weak potency for inhibiting IDO1 in cellular assays, despite effective activities in enzymatic assays, which might be explained by poor membrane permeability.(106)

    N-Hydroxyamidine Derivatives

    The N-hydroxyamidine scaffold was initially identified through HTS of Incyteâs corporate collection and led to the discovery of 30 (Figure 4, INCB14943) as a potential lead with nanomolar activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 75 nM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 19 nM).(76,108) Further optimization of incorporating polar side chains at the C4-position of the amino-furazan core provided highly potent derivatives with improved PK profiles, including clinical candidate 2 (hIDO1 IC50 = 73 nM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 7.4 nM).(76) As described above, the N-hydroxyamidine derivatives were mostly observed to coordinate heme iron with the O atom and occupy both pockets A and B with the halogenated phenyl and their side chain, respectively.(34,109,110) One exception is that 30 was reported to bind to the heme iron through the N atom of the oxime moiety (Figure 4, PDB id: 5XE1).(111) Subsequently, RÃ¶hrig et al. published their work in resolving the optimized binding mode of 30 in IDO1 using combined in silico calculations and proposed that compounds of the N-hydroxyamidine family are prone to bind through their deprotonated oxygen atom to heme.(112) It has been recognized that the Nâ²-halogenphenyl-1,2,5-oxadiazole-3-carboximidamide core plays a fundamental role in IDO1 inhibition, while the side chain at the C4-position shows a minor impact on potency. Recently reported N-hydroxyamidine-based inhibitors usually exhibit nanomolar activities with well-designed side chains for various purposes, including pursuing better PK profiles or multitargeting effects (Figure 4). In 2019, Zhang et al. reported a series of N-hydroxyamidine derivatives through the rigidification strategy based on the original HTS hit of 30.(110) Among them, 31 (Figure 4) emerged and selectively inhibited IDO1 with IC50 values of 81 nM and 49 nM in the enzymatic and HeLa cellular assays, respectively.(110) After screening side chains, 31 exhibited the best potential as a combination of good IDO1 inhibition and improved metabolic stability.(110) Recently, a group of phosphonamidite-based derivatives was screened and discovered as potential IDO1 inhibitors and initially found that lead 32 (Figure 4) showed the most potent in vitro and in vivo activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 104 nM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 10.1 nM).(113) Furthermore, derivative 33 (Figure 4) with an extended side chain was identified with improved antitumor efficacies in multiple in vivo models, which could be ascribed to enhanced Trp-Kyn pathway inhibition according to subsequent evaluation.(114) It was found that 33 exhibits pan activities across the three Trp metabolism enzymes IDO1/IDO2/TDO (hIDO1 IC50 = 94 nM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 12.6 nM, hIDO2 IC50 = 310 nM, hTDO IC50 = 2.6 Î¼M), which may account for the enhanced potencies.(114) Recently, Mengâs group reported N-hydroxyamidine IDO1 inhibitors based on a cyclizing strategy that showed improved PK profiles and optimal safety.(115,116) Cycling the sulfamoylamino component of 2 led to 34 (Figure 4) with IC50 values of 56.2 nM and 33 nM in enzymatic and cellular assays, respectively.(115) In addition, by incorporating a piperidine group into the side chain, 35 (Figure 4) was obtained with improved PK properties, despite diminished IDO1 inhibitory activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 178 nM, HEK293T IDO1 IC50 = 68 nM).(116) In more recent studies, N-hydroxyamidine inhibitors with sulfonamide groups were reported. Steeneck et al. developed a sulfonamide-based derivative, 36 (Figure 4), bearing a thioether-containing side chain that exhibited potent activities for IDO1 inhibition (hIDO1 IC50 = 21 nM, SKOV3 IDO1 IC50 = 10 nM) and improved metabolic stability against the glucuronidation pathway.(117) In subsequent work, another sulfonamide-based derivative, 37 (Figure 4), with a shorter side chain was reported by Zhaoâs group with nanomolar activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 71 nM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 11 nM).(118) In our previous work, isoindoline-based 38 (Figure 4) was identified as a selective moderate IDO1 inhibitor (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 1.57 Î¼M) with efficient in vivo antitumor effects.(119) It was speculated that the potential metabolites of 38 might be much more effective in triggering tumor regression.(119)
    In addition, maintaining the N-hydroxyamidine moiety, introducing a nitrobenzofurazan group at the Nâ²-position, led to 39 (Figure 4) with a distinct scaffold as a competitive IDO1 inhibitor.(120) Compound 39 was observed to selectively inhibit IDO1 in enzymatic (hIDO1 IC50 = 59 nM) and cellular tests (MDA-MB-231 IDO1 IC50 = 50 nM) with negligible cytotoxicity. In 2017, Lee et al. reported indazole-carboximidamide 40 (Figure 4) with moderate activity of IDO1 inhibition (HEK293 IDO1 IC50 = 2.13 Î¼M).(121)

    Inhibitors Targeting apo-IDO1

    Heme-Competitive Inhibitors

    As described above, apo-IDO1 has emerged as a potential target, which is further supported by recent literature. To our knowledge, most currently identified inhibitors in this class were discovered through HTS, and the mechanism of inhibition remains controversial (see the Structure and Active Sites of IDO1 section). It was demonstrated that these inhibitors showed the most potent activities in cellular assays with low nanomolar to picomolar cellular IC50 values. In addition to clinical candidate 3, N-aryl urea derivative 41 (BMS978587, Figure 5A) was initially described in the published patent application of Bristol-Myers Squibb and subsequently reported to target apo-IDO1 with potent activity (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 4.2 nM).(35,122) The crystal structure of the hIDO1â41 complex (PDB id: 6AZV, Figure 5A) revealed that the methylphenyl group extends to pocket A in a similar orientation as 3/BMS116, while the 2-aminophenylurea core occupies the vacated heme pocket. H-bonds were observed between the carboxyl group and residues, including Ala264 and His346, the latter being a key residue for stabilizing the heme group. Unlike 3, the diisobutylamino group of 41 did not extend deeply to pocket D, which may indicate that a bulky group is required. Simultaneously, in a preprint study by GlaxoSmithKline, another N-aryl urea derivative, 42 (GSK5628, Figure 5A), was reported to exhibit robust IDO1 inhibition in a cellular assay (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 5.9 nM) and in an enzymatic assay (hIDO1 IC50 = 39 nM) when the preincubation time and temperature were increased.(40) A similar mechanism of inhibition was demonstrated: 42 targeted IDO1 in its apo-form prevented the reloading of heme due to a higher binding affinity for apo-IDO1.(40) Further details of N-aryl urea derivatives reported in recent years are classified and summarized in the following group (Figure 6).
    More recently, a novel class of IDO1 inhibitors bearing a spiro piperidine-chromane motif was discovered by GlaxoSmithKline by screening a unique indole-based DNA-encoded library. Compound 43 (Figure 5B) emerged as the most potent molecule with low nanomolar activities in PBMC (IDO1 IC50 = 5.4 nM) and HeLa (IDO1 IC50 = 7.9 nM) assays.(42) SAR studies revealed that the S-conformation was essential for activity, as a 300-fold loss of potency was observed when testing the R-enantiomer. A much improved IC50 value (hIDO1 IC50 = 66.1 nM) of 43 in the enzymatic assay was obtained at a higher incubation temperature of 37 Â°C, while 43 was inactive at the common temperature of 25 Â°C. The spectroscopic study revealed that 43 is consistent with the known heme-competitive IDO1 inhibitor 42, further indicating that 43 targets apo-IDO1 for inhibition. Importantly, a prodrug approach was deployed, as 43 exhibited poor solubility and bioavailability, and a phosphonooxymethyl prodrug was thus developed with significantly improved PK profiles.
    Subsequently, Merck reported their work in discovering heme-competitive inhibitors 45 and 46 (Figure 5C). Initial hit 44 was identified through a mass spectrometry-based HTS with potent activities (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 9.2 nM, human unbound whole blood (hWBu) IDO1 IC50 = 22 nM) and served as a promising lead for optimization.(41) Further incorporation of polarity into the molecular scaffold for improving metabolic stability and solubility led to 2-pyridyl oxetane analogue 45 with improved PK profiles and enhanced cellular potencies (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 3.2 nM, hWBu IDO1 IC50 = 0.6 nM). Crystalline results of the initial hit 44 and IDO1 complex (PDB id: 6V52, Figure 5C) revealed that the inhibitor actually binds to apo-IDO1 by occupying both pockets A and D in a binding mode similar to that of BMS116. In their subsequent work, efforts to improve the metabolic stability of these compounds were made and reported. It was reported that hydrolysis of the amide bond of the benzamide moiety could be a major issue for in vitro and in vivo metabolic instability. Displacing the central 1,4-substituted aromatic moiety with a saturated bicyclo[1.1.1]pentane moiety led to 46 with improved metabolic stability, potent HeLa IDO1 inhibitory activity (IC50 = 1.9 nM), and equipotent uncorrected WB activity (hWB IDO1 IC50 = 36 nM).(43) It should be noted that the compounds with bicycloalkyl moieties usually show inferior WB potency relative to the aryl ring-bearing compounds, which may be explained by plasma protein binding issues.

    N-Aryl Urea Derivatives

    Apart from the aforementioned verified heme-competitive inhibitors 41â42, derivatives bearing this scaffold were reported with SAR in recent years (Figure 6A,B). Compounds in this class usually show single-digit nanomolar activities in the cell-based assay, which may be due to the specific inhibitory mechanism, although most of the inhibitors were not experimentally verified. 47 (Figure 6A) was developed by Bristol-Meyers Squib as a derivative of 41. By introducing isoxazole and cyclohexyl groups, a 4-fold increase in cellular activity (HEK293 IDO1 IC50 = 0.5 nM) was obtained from 47.(122) Subsequently, Williams and Markwalder et al. from Bristol-Myers Squibb reported the discovery of 48â49 as IDO1 inhibitors. Compound 48 (Figure 6A) was identified from the initial optimization effort of an HTS hit from the Bristol-Myers Squibb compound library to inhibit IDO1 with an IC50 value of 22 nM in the HeLa assay but also showed high lipophilicity (clogP = 7.8) and poor aqueous solubility.(123) Replacing the aryl ether moiety with a dialkylamino group and incorporating the carboxylic acid mimicking the 1H-tetrazole group reduced lipophilicity and led to the most potent compound 49 (Figure 6A) of the series (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 4 nM).(124)
    Recently, Zhang et al. reported their work in developing N-aryl urea derivatives 50 and 51 as IDO1 inhibitors. Heterocyclic groups, including furan and thiadiazole, were incorporated into the N-aryl urea core, which slightly shifted the cellular potency of 50 (Figure 6A, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 4.0 nM).(125) In their subsequent work, 51 was reported as an IDO1 inhibitor that exhibited enhanced cellular activities (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 2.6 nM) and was demonstrated to impede tumor growth in vivo.(126) However, the authors claimed that 50 and 51 bind to heme, which should be reconsidered and experimentally validated due to the compoundâs high structural similarities to the heme-competitive inhibitors 41 and 42.

    Multifunctional Conjugates

    The efficacy of IDO1 inhibitors as single agents in treating tumors has proven limited, which has prompted investigations on combination therapy with various agents. Based on this, chimeric compounds bearing IDO1 inhibitor scaffolds in conjugation with selected biofunctional moieties have been designed in recent years. In 2015, Pt(IV)-1 conjugate 52 (Figure 7A) was reported by Lippard et al. as a combination of IDO inhibition and DNA cross-link-triggered apoptosis, which could either block Kyn production or induce cell death across ovarian cancer cell lines in vitro.(127) Subsequently, Gou et al. reported Pt(IV) complex 53 (Figure 7A) derived from cisplatin and an IDO1/TDO inhibitor(128) and demonstrated its efficacy in tumor-bearing mice.(129)
    Based on the well-studied N-hydroxyamidine scaffold, Sheng et al. merged two known anticancer agents into an IDO1 inhibitor, which afforded dual-target molecules 54 and 55 (Figure 7B). As shown, incorporating the DNA targeting nitrogen mustard into the side chain of 2 led to 54 but decreased the IDO1 inhibitory activity (hIDO1 IC50 = 130 nM, HeLa IDO1 EC50 = 270 nM).(130) Hybrid molecule 54 exhibited improved antiproliferative activities by triggering apoptosis and inducing tumor regression in vivo. Compound 55 was reported as an IDO1/histone deacetylase (HDAC, an anticancer target) dual inhibitor, comprising a combination of 2 and a benzamide group, which is a specific Zn iron-binding moiety targeting HDAC protein. Conjugate 55 inherited nanomolar inhibitory activities toward both target enzymes (hIDO1 IC50 = 69.0 nM, HeLa EC50 = 23 nM, HDAC IC50 = 66.5 nM) and exhibited enhanced antitumor efficacy in Lewis lung cancer tumor-bearing mice.(131)
    In more recent studies, dual-function conjugates comprising IDO1/TDO and tubulin (an anticancer target) inhibitors were reported by Gou et al. 1, and a quinone inhibitor(132) was connected with the natural tubulin inhibitor CA-4 via click chemistry, which led to 56 and 57 (Figure 7C), respectively.(133,134) Comprehensive studies revealed that these compounds inhibit tumor growth with higher potencies and induce T cell activation and proliferation.
    Proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs) serve as heterobifunctional chimeric molecules that function to induce target protein degradation via the ubiquitinâproteasome pathway and have been a research focus for years.(135) Hu et al. recently reported an IDO1âPROTAC molecule 58 (Figure 7D) that comprises a substructure of 2 as the ligand for IDO1 and a cereblon (CRBN) ligand pomalidomide for E3 ligase. PROTAC 58 was reported to induce IDO1 degradation in stimulated HeLa cells with half of the degradation concentration value (DC50) of 2.84 Î¼M and to exhibit micromolar IDO1 inhibitory activity and cytotoxicity in HeLa cells (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 1.07 Î¼M, HeLa CC50 = 37.43 Î¼M).(136) Despite the rationality of the IDO1 degradation strategy, the degradation potency of 58 was actually insufficient compared to other reported PROTACs (subnanomolar to picomolar DC50s), and importantly, 58 was not demonstrated to reduce Kyn levels.

    Inhibitor Modulating ITIM Site

    The 2-propanol analogue 59 (Figure 7E) was discovered by Orabona et al. to be a specific IDO1 modulator of the NTD functional domain ITIMs, which was reported to induce IDO1 activity inhibition in a murine cellular assay (IC50 = 11.4 Î¼M) but was incompetent in an enzymatic assay.(137) It was demonstrated that 59 positively activated the ITIM-mediated signaling of IDO1 and conferred an immunosuppressive phenotype in plasmacytoid dendritic cells (DCs) in vivo.

    Other IDO1 Inhibitors

    Naturally Derived Inhibitors

    Natural products have been a fundamental source for discovering novel scaffolds as a potential lead for IDO1 inhibitors.(15) Norharman was the first known natural product inhibitor of IDO1 with weak activity (Ki = 180 Î¼M) for decades.(95,138) In 2006, various naphthoquinones were identified and reported as IDO1 inhibitors for the first time, including menadione and annulin derivatives with submicromolar activities.(139,140) Since then, quinone-based inhibitors have received significant attention, especially for previously identified Î²-lapachone (Ki = 0.1 Î¼M to IDO1), which entered phase 2 evaluations as an anticancer agent and is involved in multiple mechanisms,(141,142) as well as other recently reported quinone derivatives.(143â145) Studies have revealed that quinones inhibit IDO1 enzymatic activity with distinct mechanisms: (i) binding to the Sa site, such as type IâIII inhibitors, or (ii) interfering with the redox cycle as a type X inhibitor. These inhibitors usually exhibit low micromolar to nanomolar activities in the enzymatic assay but less potency in cellular assays, as quinones undergo NQO1-dependent redox cycling in the cellular environment.(44) In 2018, Meng et al. reported a series of naphthoquinone derivatives as potent IDO1 inhibitors. Among them, indolizinoquinoline-5,12-dione 60 (Figure 8A) showed the most potent activity in the enzymatic assay (hIDO1 IC50 = 23 nM); however, similar inhibition was not observed in the HeLa IDO1 assay.(146) Interestingly, it was demonstrated that the hydrophilic thiourea group provided the greatest improvement in enzymatic inhibition but impeded cellular activities, as one analogue exhibited an IC50 value of 372 nM in the HeLa IDO1 assay. In their parallel work, naphthothiazole, 61 (Figure 8A), was synthesized and showed nanomolar activities against both IDO1 and TDO in an enzymatic assay (hIDO1 IC50 = 18 nM, hTDO IC50 = 214 nM).(147) SAR studies revealed that replacing the 4-thiazole group with a 4-pyridine group significantly weakened activity toward TDO but showed less impact on the IDO1 inhibitory activity. Through screening an in-house compound library of natural products, compound 62 (Figure 8A) with a furanonaphthoquinone scaffold was identified as a potential lead IDO1 inhibitor with a micromolar IC50 value in the cellular assay (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 1.01 Î¼M).(144) A naphthoquinone derivative, 63 (Figure 8A), emerged as a VS hit, which was demonstrated to have moderate IDO1 cellular activities (SKOV3 IDO1 IC50 > 40 Î¼M) and higher potency in the dual IDO1/TDO-expressing cell line BT549 (IC50 = 3.42 Î¼M).(148) Recently, a set of well-designed naphthoquinone derivatives in conjunction with amide-oxime groups were reported to be potent IDO1 inhibitors and effective anticancer agents. A nanomolar enzymatic IC50 value was reported for 64 (Figure 8A, hIDO1 IC50 = 46 nM), which was subsequently demonstrated to bind to IDO1 and directly interact with ferric heme.(149) Cellular IDO1 inhibitory activities of these compounds were not reported, presumably due to the nanomolar cytotoxicity toward various cancer cell lines. SAR studies revealed that the oxime group was essential for IDO1 inhibition, and substituents of the phenylamino group showed a significant influence on enzymatic activities, which was proposed to occupy pocket B. Similar to previous reports, the antiproliferative activities of naphthoquinone derivative 64 were simultaneously confirmed with nanomolar IC50 values against multiple cancer cell lines by suppressing the signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) signaling.(149) Benzoquinone 65 (Figure 8A) was derived from coenzyme-Q1 and reported to inhibit IDO1 with micromolar activities in enzymatic and cellular assays (hIDO1 IC50 = 0.13 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 11.2 Î¼M), which could also induce equivalent cytotoxicity toward the HEK293T cell line (IC50 = 28 Î¼M).(150) In a recent study, indoledione 66 (Figure 8A) was reported as a derivative of bioactive natural products and exhibited IC50 values of 160 nM and 3.58 Î¼M in enzymatic and cellular assays, respectively.(151) However, cellular toxicities of this compound should be measured to clarify the cellular IDO1 inhibitory activities. Despite better in vitro IDO enzymatic activities, quinones usually show less cellular inhibitory potency but higher cellular toxicity and other activities. In general, quinones may be pan assay interference compounds (PAINS)(152) that are involved in multiple mechanisms. Therefore, the target selectivity and safety of quinones should be validated prior to further evaluation. However, the multitarget effect of quinone IDO1 inhibitors may be an advantage, as selective IDO1 inhibitors have shown limited benefit in clinical trials, namely, combining the effect of immune elimination by modulating Trp metabolism and cellular toxicity (e.g., NQO1/IDO1 dual-target compounds). Hence, in our view, quinone IDO1 inhibitors also show potential for drug discovery and clinical evaluation, but potential toxicity should be noted.
    In 2013, the natural product tryptanthrin was discovered to inhibit IDO1 in both enzymatic and cellular assays and showed anticancer efficacy in vivo.(153) Distinguished from quinones, tryptanthrin derivatives usually displayed higher inhibitory efficiencies in cell-based assays, and recent studies have indicated that these natural analogues could show equal potency for TDO inhibition.(154â156) 8-Fluoro-substituted tryptanthrin 67 (Figure 8B) exhibited dual inhibitory activities toward IDO1/TDO with nanomolar IC50 values in cellular assays (HEK293 IDO1 IC50 = 23 nM, HEK293 TDO IC50 = 68 nM).(153,154) Incorporating a dimethylamino methyl group into the C2-position of 67 further enhanced the cellular inhibitory activities across IDO1/IDO2/TDO (68, Figure 8B, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 20 nM, U87 MG IDO2 IC50 = 3.81 Î¼M, HEK293 TDO IC50 = 60 nM).(155) Replacement of the N-alkyl moiety with the Î²-acrylic acid group led to an approximately 30-fold increase in TDO enzymatic activity (69, Figure 8B, hIDO1 IC50 = 120 nM, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 60 nM, hTDO IC50 = 30 nM) but did not improve IDO1 activity.(156) Interestingly, it was demonstrated that the tryptanthrin derivative directly interacts with the three target proteins, while coordination to heme iron was not observed.(153)
    In addition, ortho-naphthoquinone derivatives, including synthetic 70 (Figure 8C) and natural product 71 (Figure 8C), were identified as IDO1 inhibitors with submicromolar activities.(157,158) In addition to quinones and tryptanthrins, some flavonoid derivatives isolated from Sophora flavescens have been recently reported as IDO1 inhibitors. Flavonoid 72 (Kushenol E, Figure 8C) exhibited micromolar activities in both enzymatic and cellular assays (hIDO1 IC50 = 7.7 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 4.3 Î¼M) and was demonstrated to directly bind to IDO1 with a Kd value of 6.5 Î¼M.(159) Compound 73 (Figure 8C) was synthesized based on the scaffold of marine-derived pyrrolopiperazinone alkaloid and identified to be a weak IDO1 inhibitor (hIDO1 IC50 = 92 Î¼M).(160)

    Other Scaffolds

    The VS strategy has significantly contributed to identifying novel inhibitors with structural features that are distinct from the aforementioned compounds. In silico screening of a commercial compound library led to Î²-naphthol 74 (Figure 9A) with micromolar activities in both enzymatic and cellular assays (hIDO1 IC50 = 18.7 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 18.2 Î¼M).(161) Docking results suggested that the Î²-hydroxyl group may participate in the coordination with heme iron. Symmetric compound 75 (Figure 9A) was discovered from VS, which reportedly inhibited IDO1 with an IC50 value of 1 nM in an enzymatic assay and displayed good selectivity in a kinome inhibition assay.(162) Lai et al. reported the discovery of potent IDO1 inhibitor 76 (Figure 9A) based on a combined VS strategy, which showed nanomolar inhibitory activity in the HeLa assay (HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 59.8 nM) and suppressed tumor growth in a murine CT26 syngeneic model.(163) Notably, despite the structural resemblance of 76 and heme-competitive inhibitor 3, the authors demonstrated that 76 may inhibit IDO1 by a discrepant mechanism, which was further supported by spectroscopic results of the initial hit compounds. In our separate work, cyanopyridine derivatives were identified as IDO1 inhibitors through a ligand-based VS campaign. Further lead optimization led to 77 (Figure 9A) with submicromolar IC50 values in the enzymatic assay (hIDO1 IC50 = 0.84 Î¼M).(47) Similar to 76, 77 was also proven to interact with heme iron; thus, the 3-cyano group was speculated to induce coordination. A recent study by Massarotti et al. described the identification of benzimidazole derivative 78 (Figure 9A) as a selective IDO1 inhibitor (A375 IDO1 IC50 = 16 nM, hIDO1 Kd = 0.55 Î¼M).(164) The linear molecule 78 emerged as a potent hit from a VS project and was able to inhibit IDO1 enzyme activity with nanomolar to submicromolar IC50 values across various cell lines. Further molecular dynamics (MD) simulations indicated that the benzimidazole moiety was stabilized in pocket A while interacting with heme iron via the N1 atom, and the bromopyrrole group could either protrude toward a distal pocket (also named pocket C(39,106)) nearing the solvent region or form cationâÏ interactions with Arg231 in pocket B. Despite the fact that 78 was proposed to coordinate to heme iron, the binding mode should be further assessed due to the high structural similarity of 78 with reported heme-competitive inhibitors. In Figure S1, the shape-based models of compounds 78, 3, and 7 are shown, and the calculated overlay similarity of the three compounds is listed to illustrate the similarity. In addition, it will be interesting and meaningful to uncover potential heme-competitive inhibitors from numerous current inhibitors in future searches. Hydrazonoindanone derivative 79 (Figure 9A) was another VS hit that was identified to inhibit IDO1 with moderate activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 2.7 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 9.1 Î¼M).(165)
    Benzenesulfonylhydrazide 80 (Figure 9B) was discovered with nanomolar inhibitory activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 36 nM, HeLa IDO1 EC50 = 68 nM) via lead optimization based on a previous HTS work.(166,167) Importantly, the lead compound bearing an acetamido group at the para-position of the phenylsulfonyl moiety was demonstrated to be potent in vitro (hIDO1 IC50 = 130 nM, HeLa IDO1 EC50 = 85 nM) but ineffective in vivo. Rigidifying the N-acetamide substituent led to oxoindole 80 with improved in vitro potency and in vivo antitumor efficacy in a murine CT26 model. Panda et al. screened a series of fused heterocyclic compounds for IDO1 inhibition and reported that dipyrazolopyran 81 (Figure 9B) showed the most potent activities (hIDO1 IC50 = 151 nM, MDA-MB-231 IDO1 EC50 = 48 nM).(168) The nearly symmetric molecule showed selectivity toward TDO and was proven to interact with the ferrous IDO1 enzyme.
    O-Arylhydroxylamines were previously identified as IDO1 inhibitors with submicromolar IC50 values in enzymatic and cellular assays.(169) Further modifying the monoaryl molecule afforded diaryl derivatives, which were initially conceived in an effort to exploit an additional pocket for enhanced potency and selectivity, as Winters et al. reported, however, provided pan or dual inhibitory activities across three dioxygenases IDO1/IDO2/TDO.(170) As shown, 82 (Figure 9B) inhibited IDO1/IDO2/TDO with IC50 values within 10 Î¼M in both enzymatic and cellular assays (hIDO1 IC50 = 3 Î¼M, HeLa IDO1 IC50 = 0.35 Î¼M).
    In 2014, certain antifungal agents, including miconazole, were identified by RÃ¶hrig et al. as potential IDO1 inhibitors by screening a library of approved drugs.(171) In a follow-up study, Lu et al. reported miconazole derivative 83 (Figure 9B) as a dual inhibitor of IDO1 and butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE) (hIDO1 IC50 = 1.0 Î¼M, BuChE IC50 = 16.5 Î¼M) for the treatment of Alzheimerâs disease (AD), which may represent an example of an âold drug for new useâ strategy in discovering IDO1 inhibitors.(172)

    Conclusions and Future Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    IDO1 catalyzes the first step of the Trp-Kyn pathway and induces immunosuppression via two proposed mechanisms: local Trp depletion and downstream metabolite accumulation. Due to its pivotal role in immune modulation, pharmacological inhibitors of IDO1 have been regarded as potential drugs for various diseases involving cancers (e.g., melanoma, lung carcinoma, bladder carcinoma), neurodegeneration (e.g., Huntingtonâs disease, Alzheimerâs disease),(3,172,173) and infection (e.g., HIV).(174)
    In recent years, numerous compounds with various chemical scaffolds (e.g., Trp analogues, N-hydroxyamidines, natural derivatives) or inhibitory mechanisms (e.g., substrate Trp/O2-competitive, heme-competitive) have been developed. The recent understanding of IDO1âs structure, function, and mechanism has significantly contributed to identifying novel IDO1 inhibitors. In this review, most of the collected inhibitors were discovered via SBDD, while the initial lead may derive from HTS, VS, and natural products. Several heme-competitive inhibitors of IDO1 have been recently discovered, and related studies have led to the identification of the additional binding pocket D and a distinct inhibitory mechanism. However, few efforts have been reported for developing heme-competitive inhibitors. Future SBDD or VS campaigns may be viable in identifying these inhibitors since several cocomplexes of heme-competitive inhibitors with IDO1 have been disclosed, and biological assays are also available.
    Eleven small-molecule drugs targeting IDO1 or the IDO pathway have entered clinical trials for the treatment of cancer, and eight of them are still under active evaluation. However, an advanced phase 3 trial (ECHO-301) on the selective IDO1 inhibitor epacadostat (2) with pembrolizumab for the treatment of melanoma did not show improved responses compared to pembrolizumab alone, raising questions on the viability of this approach and the need for greater understanding of the Trp-Kyn pathway.(3) This failure frustrated the research community and prompted the suspension of several ongoing pivotal trials. Incytes terminated all of phase 3 trials of epacadostat (2) after negative results of the ECHO-301 trial. Bristol-Myers Squibb suspended two phase 3 trials of linrodostat (3) in HNSCC and NSCLC, while NewLink Genetics halted a phase 2/3 study of indoximod (1) in melanoma. Queries and comments have also been addressed regarding this trial design, including the following: (i) the dose of 100 mg BID in ECHO-301 may not have been sufficient to reduce Kyn levels and block immunosuppressive effects, which requires further deliberation; (ii) patient populations were not stratified according to IDO1 expression; and (iii) a potential compensatory metabolic pathway of Trp involving TDO and/or IDO2 exists and (iv) other combined therapy choices.(1,22,23) Hence, comprehensive consideration of the indications, therapeutic combinations, and trial designs may be required prior to resuming phase 3 trials.(22,23,48)
    In small-molecule drug discovery, exploring Trp-Kyn pathway inhibitors or new IDO1 inhibition mechanisms and strategies might be the next approach. The combination of IDO/TDO dual inhibition and downstream signaling (e.g., AhR) blockade may represent an improved solution for fully inhibiting the Trp-Kyn pathway. Notably, two IDO1/TDO inhibitors and the first AhR antagonist entered clinical trials as cancer immunotherapies in 2019.(175) On the other hand, increasing apo-IDO1 targeted inhibitors have been recently reported, and at least 2 of them are still under active clinical evaluation (linrodostat (3) and KHK-2455). Except for better enzymatic inhibitory activities, apo-targeting inhibitors do not induce inadvertent AhR agonism, which, however, could be activated by several heme-binding inhibitors, including epacadostat (2).(80,176,177)
    Recently reported analogues of clinical heme-binding inhibitors have shown improvement in various fields, including inhibitory potency and PK profiles, which may still be a possible approach in IDO1 inhibitor discovery. For example, tricyclic derivative 24 showed improvement in enzymatic inhibitory activity and metabolic stability compared to navoximod (4). N-Hydroxyamidine derivative 31 showed improved oral bioavailability and drug clearance, whereas epacadostat (2) suffered a short half-life; thus, BID was required. Meanwhile, developing epacadostat (2) or N-hydroxyamidine derivatives is still an appealing approach, which may be further supported by the fact that select phase 1/2 studies of epacadostat are currently recruiting. The use of novel IDO1 inhibitors and those listed in this review should help to increase our understanding of the pharmacological roles of the Trp-Kyn pathway, allowing IDO1 inhibitors to potentially successfully contribute to the treatment of cancer and other diseases in the future.

      Metabolomic adaptations and correlates of survival to immune checkpoint blockade
      Li Haoxin; Gurjao Carino; Braun David; Shukla Sachet A; Bosse Dominick; Lalani Aly-Khan A; Signoretti Sabina; Freeman Gordon J; Van Allen Eliezer M; Stephen Hodi F; Sellers William R; Garraway Levi A; Choueiri Toni K; Giannakis Marios; Li Haoxin; Bullock Kevin; Gurjao Carino; Gopal Shuba; Van Allen Eliezer M; Schreiber Stuart L; Sellers William R; Garraway Levi A; Clish Clary B; Giannakis Marios; Li Haoxin; Schreiber Stuart L; Jin Chelsea; Horak Christine; Wind-Rotolo Megan; McDermott David F; Van Allen Eliezer M; Stephen Hodi F; Garraway Levi A; Choueiri Toni K; Giannakis Marios
      Nature communications (2019), 10 (1), 4346 ISSN:.
      Despite remarkable success of immune checkpoint inhibitors, the majority of cancer patients have yet to receive durable benefits. Here, in order to investigate the metabolic alterations in response to immune checkpoint blockade, we comprehensively profile serum metabolites in advanced melanoma and renal cell carcinoma patients treated with nivolumab, an antibody against programmed cell death protein 1 (PD1). We identify serum kynurenine/tryptophan ratio increases as an adaptive resistance mechanism associated with worse overall survival. This advocates for patient stratification and metabolic monitoring in immunotherapy clinical trials including those combining PD1 blockade with indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase/tryptophan 2,3-dioxygenase (IDO/TDO) inhibitors.

      Platten, M.; Nollen, E. A. A.; Rohrig, U. F.; Fallarino, F.; Opitz, C. A. Tryptophan Metabolism as a Common Therapeutic Target in Cancer, Neurodegeneration and Beyond. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2019, 18, 379â 401, Â DOI: 10.1038/s41573-019-0016-5

      Tryptophan metabolism as a common therapeutic target in cancer, neurodegeneration and beyond
      Platten, Michael; Nollen, Ellen A. A.; Roehrig, Ute F.; Fallarino, Francesca; Opitz, Christiane A.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2019), 18 (5), 379-401CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Research)
      A review. L-Tryptophan (Trp) metab. through the kynurenine pathway (KP) is involved in the regulation of immunity, neuronal function and intestinal homeostasis. Imbalances in Trp metab. in disorders ranging from cancer to neurodegenerative disease have stimulated interest in therapeutically targeting the KP, particularly the main rate-limiting enzymes indoleamine-2,3-dioxygenase 1 (IDO1), IDO2 and tryptophan-2,3-dioxygenase (TDO) as well as kynurenine monooxygenase (KMO). However, although small-mol. IDO1 inhibitors showed promise in early-stage cancer immunotherapy clin. trials, a phase III trial was neg. This Review summarizes the physiol. and pathophysiol. roles of Trp metab., highlighting the vast opportunities and challenges for drug development in multiple diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Liu, Y.; Liang, X.; Dong, W.; Fang, Y.; Lv, J.; Zhang, T.; Fiskesund, R.; Xie, J.; Liu, J.; Yin, X.; Jin, X.; Chen, D.; Tang, K.; Ma, J.; Zhang, H.; Yu, J.; Yan, J.; Liang, H.; Mo, S.; Cheng, F.; Zhou, Y.; Zhang, H.; Wang, J.; Li, J.; Chen, Y.; Cui, B.; Hu, Z. W.; Cao, X.; Xiao-Feng Qin, F.; Huang, B. Tumor-Repopulating Cells Induce Pd-1 Expression in Cd8(+) T Cells by Transferring Kynurenine and Ahr Activation. Cancer Cell 2018, 33, 480â 494, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.ccell.2018.02.005
